scenarioDescription:
The LSPM J2116+0234 Exoplanetary System


Overview

LSPM J2116+0234 is a star with 0.43 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.43 times its radius. It is located 57.50 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 2 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

LSPM J2116+0234 is known to have 1 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the LSPM J2116+0234 system


LSPM J2116+0234 b

LSPM J2116+0234 b was discovered by the Calar Alto Observatory observatory, in 2019-07, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.09 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of LSPM J2116+0234 b is 13.308 times the mass of Earth. The radius of LSPM J2116+0234 b is 3.710 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, LSPM J2116+0234 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system LSPM J2116+0234, which contains 1 exoplanets and was discovered by the Calar Alto Observatory.
name: LSPM J2116+0234 - System With 1 Exoplanet
